Data: feature          24 comments       Why Girls und Panzer Works So Well   Apr 20, 21:00 24 comments                 anime    Who would've thought that a series about high school girls in short skirts fighting tank battles would be the peak of military-themed anime? ― CGDCT, or “Cute Girls Doing Cute Things,” is a genre in anime that usually revolves around a high school setting where cute girls in school uniforms talk about love, discuss fashion, go shopping, share a hobby, and do other things without a single guy in sight...

Co-author Shaenon Garrity counts down her favorite manga from the column. ―  Shaenon's Ten Favorite 'House' Manga It falls upon my bowed shoulders to announce the news: House of 1,000 Manga is ending. After five years of weekly columns, the time has come to move on. Among other things, we're kind of running out of...                           column          26 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Kekkaishi   2015 Jun 18, 22:15 26 comments                 manga    Jason exorcises some demons with the teenage spirit-banishing crew of Kekkaishi, a 35-volume action adventure hit. ―  Kekkaishi Manga years are like dog years; a popular shonen or shojo manga lives for 10 or so years, it has a rich, full life (or not), and after it's gone you remember it fondly. (Unless it's a manga that keeps dragging on forever on life support, getting worse and worse and draining ...                    column          43 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Five Amazing Untranslated Manga   2015 Jun 11, 22:56 43 comments                 manga    Shaenon uncovers five incredible manga that, for whatever silly reason, haven't been made legally available in English yet, including one by the author of Fullmetal Alchemist. ―  Five Amazing Untranslated Manga When I tell people I work as a manga editor, one of the first and most reasonable questions I get is, “Oh, you read Japanese?” Sadly, no. All I bring to the job are my Seven Sisters-honed writ...                    column          4 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Meteor Prince   2015 Jun  4, 23:01 4 comments                 manga    In a mad scramble to find a manga to review this week, Jason rolls the dice and winds up with a magic space boyfriend falling right on his head. ―  Meteor Prince 10 a.m., Wednesday. House of 1000 Manga is due in four hours, and I've read everything in the house. Drinking coffee is just making me more nervous and jittery, and making me think, when will someone translate a coffee-themed manga? Is Rei H...                    column          6 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Sunny   2015 May 28, 23:00 6 comments                 manga    The acclaimed author of Gogo Monster turns in a highly personal series of vignettes that offer a peek into his life. ―  Sunny In my House column on Taiyo Matsumoto's GoGo Monster, I mentioned how the alt-manga master's career has drifted from fantasy to realism, toward work that feels increasingly drawn from life. Best known in the U.S. for Tekkon Kinkreet (also published as Black and White), a sci-f...                    column          20 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Inuyashiki   2015 May 22, 00:00 20 comments                 manga    An old man becomes a cybernetic killing machine courtesy of the author of Gantz. Just don't get between him and the early bird special. ―  Inuyashiki “When I see old men eating beef bowls alone, late at night…lonely old salarymen…I wonder what their joy in life is. Why are they eating alone? Don’t they have families to be with?” I almost read a YA shojo manga for this week, but instead, somehow, I'm ...                    column          8 comments       House of 1000 Manga - The Earl and the Fairy   2015 May 15, 00:00 8 comments                 manga    A plucky redheaded fairy expert gets more than she bargained for, along with a magical boyfriend. Shaenon investigates. ―  The Earl and the Fairy I admit it: I feel like I'm behind on the shojo manga these days. The most popular shonen series make enough noise in fandom that even an old Dirty Pair-reading fart like myself knows more or less what's up, and anyway right now it's mostly Attack on Titan ...                    column          10 comments       House of 1000 Manga - Poverty, Princesses and Zombies   2015 May  8, 00:00 10 comments                 manga    Jason checks out three prose novels about the life and challenges of working as a mangaka. ―  The Poverty, The Princess and the Zombies The way reading about food makes you hungry, reading about manga makes me want to read manga. Back to top                  Charou    Joined: 01 May 2018 		    Posts: 106 		    Location: Sydney, Australia 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 9:50 pm            Chances of an Australian screening pretty much zero, but if this means a bluray release is imminent, that more than satisfies me -- the bluray of the series is excellently done. I'm listening to the movie OST right now and I'm pretty sure it's my favourite 'anime series' movie, ever. It addressed character tensions established and exploited by the show, handled an oversight regarding one particular stage girl not getting her moment, and it evolved all the themes to a level of surreal extravagance expected of a student of the Ikuhara school of WTFness. And unlike a lot of anime series movies, it didn't really have 'stand out sakuga' moments between tv-level production scenes -- the whole thing was gorgeous.   Unfortunately it does sort of rely on having seen the recap movie (or at least what it does differently near the end) but, much like Heaven's Feel 1, this is one of those movies of such superior quality that you want to recommend to ANYONE who likes anime, 'getting it all' be damned. Back to top                  Charou    Joined: 01 May 2018 		    Posts: 106 		    Location: Sydney, Australia 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 9:50 pm            Chances of an Australian screening pretty much zero, but if this means a bluray release is imminent, that more than satisfies me -- the bluray of the series is excellently done. I'm listening to the movie OST right now and I'm pretty sure it's my favourite 'anime series' movie, ever. It addressed character tensions established and exploited by the show, handled an oversight regarding one particular stage girl not getting her moment, and it evolved all the themes to a level of surreal extravagance expected of a student of the Ikuhara school of WTFness. And unlike a lot of anime series movies, it didn't really have 'stand out sakuga' moments between tv-level production scenes -- the whole thing was gorgeous.   Unfortunately it does sort of rely on having seen the recap movie (or at least what it does differently near the end) but, much like Heaven's Feel 1, this is one of those movies of such superior quality that you want to recommend to ANYONE who likes anime, 'getting it all' be damned. Northeast coverage is lousy too (two theaters each in NYC and Boston). Nothing in south Florida. Pathetic.   Belle somehow managed to play 2-4 shows a day for six weeks here in Grand Rapids. At this point, I think I'm just going to ignore any theatrical anime release that isn't through GKids. It isn't even worth looking at the theater list with anyone else.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3817       Posted: Thu Apr 21, 2022 7:46 pm            I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.       Quote:    Belle somehow managed to play 2-4 shows a day for six weeks here in Grand Rapids. At this point, I think I'm just going to ignore any theatrical anime release that isn't through GKids. It isn't even worth looking at the theater list with anyone else.         It would be nice if they could expand further but you have to have realistic expectations that Belle is a major stand alone studio film by a prominent film director while Revue Starlight is a sequel to a niche surrealist anime that didn't exactly set the streaming world on fire when it came out.  It's amazing it's being released in US theaters at all.  And you also have to take into account GKids is a much bigger company with more money and resources than Sentai. It isn't even worth looking at the theater list with anyone else.            they've added a Marcus theater in Columbus, which have very comfortable red leather recliners, very plush.  Though that is a bit of a trek from Grand Rapids.  And there's still plenty of time to add more theaters   https://www.sentaifilmworks.com/a/news/book-your-ticket-to-see-revue-starlight-the-movie-in-theaters?utm_medium=site&utm_source=sfw&utm_campaign=rsm&utm_term=theatricaltab      Back to top                  Angel M Cazares   Subscriber   Joined: 23 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 4939 		    Location: Iscandar 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 10:43 am              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:    I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.           I hope Sentai has has the full license.  I don't want a repeat of the Shirobako movie.      Back to top                   dragonrider_cody    Joined: 14 Jun 2008 		    Posts: 2527       Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 3:27 pm              Angel M Cazares wrote:       Cardcaptor Takato wrote:    I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.           I hope Sentai has has the full license.  I don't want a repeat of the Shirobako movie.            They should.  I doubt they would license a movie for just one limited showing in theaters.      Back to top                  Charou    Joined: 01 May 2018 		    Posts: 106 		    Location: Sydney, Australia 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 9:50 pm            Chances of an Australian screening pretty much zero, but if this means a bluray release is imminent, that more than satisfies me -- the bluray of the series is excellently done. I'm listening to the movie OST right now and I'm pretty sure it's my favourite 'anime series' movie, ever. It addressed character tensions established and exploited by the show, handled an oversight regarding one particular stage girl not getting her moment, and it evolved all the themes to a level of surreal extravagance expected of a student of the Ikuhara school of WTFness. And unlike a lot of anime series movies, it didn't really have 'stand out sakuga' moments between tv-level production scenes -- the whole thing was gorgeous.   Unfortunately it does sort of rely on having seen the recap movie (or at least what it does differently near the end) but, much like Heaven's Feel 1, this is one of those movies of such superior quality that you want to recommend to ANYONE who likes anime, 'getting it all' be damned. Northeast coverage is lousy too (two theaters each in NYC and Boston). Nothing in south Florida. Pathetic.   Belle somehow managed to play 2-4 shows a day for six weeks here in Grand Rapids. At this point, I think I'm just going to ignore any theatrical anime release that isn't through GKids. It isn't even worth looking at the theater list with anyone else.      Back to top                  Cardcaptor Takato    Joined: 27 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 3817       Posted: Thu Apr 21, 2022 7:46 pm            I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.       Quote:    Belle somehow managed to play 2-4 shows a day for six weeks here in Grand Rapids. At this point, I think I'm just going to ignore any theatrical anime release that isn't through GKids. It isn't even worth looking at the theater list with anyone else.         It would be nice if they could expand further but you have to have realistic expectations that Belle is a major stand alone studio film by a prominent film director while Revue Starlight is a sequel to a niche surrealist anime that didn't exactly set the streaming world on fire when it came out.  It's amazing it's being released in US theaters at all.  And you also have to take into account GKids is a much bigger company with more money and resources than Sentai. Though that is a bit of a trek from Grand Rapids.  And there's still plenty of time to add more theaters   https://www.sentaifilmworks.com/a/news/book-your-ticket-to-see-revue-starlight-the-movie-in-theaters?utm_medium=site&utm_source=sfw&utm_campaign=rsm&utm_term=theatricaltab      Back to top                  Angel M Cazares   Subscriber   Joined: 23 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 4939 		    Location: Iscandar 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 10:43 am              Cardcaptor Takato wrote:    I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.           I hope Sentai has has the full license.  I don't want a repeat of the Shirobako movie.      Back to top                   dragonrider_cody    Joined: 14 Jun 2008 		    Posts: 2527       Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 3:27 pm              Angel M Cazares wrote:       Cardcaptor Takato wrote:    I really enjoyed the Revue Starlight series but I almost forgot about this movie but I'm glad Sentai has licensed it.           I hope Sentai has has the full license.  I don't want a repeat of the Shirobako movie.            They should.  I doubt they would license a movie for just one limited showing in theaters.      Back to top                  Charou    Joined: 01 May 2018 		    Posts: 106 		    Location: Sydney, Australia 		        Posted: Fri Apr 22, 2022 9:50 pm            Chances of an Australian screening pretty much zero, but if this means a bluray release is imminent, that more than satisfies me -- the bluray of the series is excellently done. I'm listening to the movie OST right now and I'm pretty sure it's my favourite 'anime series' movie, ever. It addressed character tensions established and exploited by the show, handled an oversight regarding one particular stage girl not getting her moment, and it evolved all the themes to a level of surreal extravagance expected of a student of the Ikuhara school of WTFness. And unlike a lot of anime series movies, it didn't really have 'stand out sakuga' moments between tv-level production scenes -- the whole thing was gorgeous.   Unfortunately it does sort of rely on having seen the recap movie (or at least what it does differently near the end) but, much like Heaven's Feel 1, this is one of those movies of such superior quality that you want to recommend to ANYONE who likes anime, 'getting it all' be damned. Data: ⬈ ⬋ - +       Forum     Jump to: Select a forum   Site-related ---------------- Announcements & The Rules Talkback Encyclopedia Bugs & Technical Questions ANN Feedback   General ---------------- Anime Series Discussion Manga Music Events Novels Video Games Polls Contests and Games   Industry ---------------- Retail   For Subscribers ---------------- Community Feature requests Collection Spotlight Personal Sales     You cannot post new topics in this forumYou cannot reply to topics in this forumYou cannot edit your posts in this forumYou cannot delete your posts in this forumYou cannot vote in polls in this forum                         news          31 comments       ONIMAI: I'm Now Your Sister! Gender-Bending Comedy Manga Gets TV Anime   Apr 24, 07:51 31 comments                 anime    Marika Kōno, Kaori Ishihara star in anime about boy waking up as girl due to sister's experiments ― Ichijinsha announced on Friday that Nekotofu's ONIMAI: I'm Now Your Sister! (Onii-chan wa Oshimai!) manga is inspiring a television anime starring Marika Kōno as protagonist Mahiro Oyama and Kaori Ishihara as Mahiro's sister Mihari Oyama. Ichijinsha is streaming a voiced motion comic video featuring th...                    news          10 comments       Nintendo of America Responds After Worker Files Labor Complaint   Apr 24, 07:50 10 comments                 industry    Anonymous employee accused Nintendo of concerted activities, coercive actions, discharge, surveillance ― Nintendo of America responded in a statement to news website Kotaku on Thursday after an anonymous employee filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board in Redmond, Washington against Nintendo and contracting company Aston Carter on April 15. The complaint accuses Nintendo and Aston C...                    news          18 comments       New Shaman King Anime Gets Sequel   Apr 24, 07:47 18 comments                 anime    Hana, other new characters teased ― The new television anime of Hiroyuki Takei's Shaman King manga ended on Tuesday with an ad announcing that a sequel has been green-lit. News futekiya Boys-Love Manga Service Licenses 10 Shonengahosha Titles   posted on 2022-04-21 05:00 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo          Ore Tachi no Hanashi wo Shiyou, Boss to Yasu, more manga    Fantasista, Inc.'s futekiya boys-love manga subscription service announced on Tuesday that it has licensed 10 new titles from Shonengahosha.     futekiya will announce release dates and English names for the following titles at a later date:     Ore Tachi no Hanashi wo Shiyou by Samba Maekawa   Boss to Yasu by Sainosuke   Koi wo Shiru niha Mada Aoi [Tankoubonban] by Ryo Ito   Gnossiennes -Seinen Tachi wa Yuukaku de Koi wo Siru- [Gassatsuban] by Makuya   Suki ni Natta Hito ga Barineko de Shita- [Gassatsuban] by Haine   Kouda-san! Uchi Kimashou! -Nigerare Otoko to Batsuichi Otoko- [Gassatsuban] by Taguru Nakamaru   Yuusha-sama no Are ga Cheatkyuu Sugite Komattemasu by Merino   Koi ni Kizuita Sono Hi kara [Gassatsuban] by Ryo Ito   Aseta Tsuki to Amai Kiba by salty   Kyou mo Futago ni Semararete masu by Kanna Aizumi    Readers are able to read select chapters from the futekiya library for free, and subscribers to the futekiya service can access full volumes.    The futekiya service launched in July 2019, and it allows access to its entire library of manga for a monthly fee of US$6.99. The service is also offering licensed dōjinshi and manga by independent artists.    Manga Planet launched in November 2019. The service costs US$6.99 per month and allows users unlimited access to English-translated manga. In addition to manga licensed from publishers, the service offers works licensed from independent artists.    Manga Planet is also working with publishers LEED Publishing Co., Ltd., Bunkasha Publishing Co., Ltd.; Kaiohsha Publishing Co., Ltd.; San-Ei Corporation Co., Ltd.; Tokuma Shoten Publishing Co., Ltd.; Shodensha Publishing Co., Ltd.; Home-sha, Starts Publishing Corporation, K.K. HarperCollins Japan, and MugenUp Inc.    Manga Planet started as a joint project between Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd. and Fantasista, Inc. in 2012. The companies' goal with Manga Planet is to "[bring] new manga to fans from all over the world and support artists and the industry."    Disclosure: futekiya's Editor-in-Chief Emma Hanashiro worked at ANN as a news intern in 2014. News futekiya Boys-Love Manga Service Licenses 10 Shonengahosha Titles   posted on 2022-04-21 05:00 UTC-8 by Alex Mateo          Ore Tachi no Hanashi wo Shiyou, Boss to Yasu, more manga    Fantasista, Inc.'s futekiya boys-love manga subscription service announced on Tuesday that it has licensed 10 new titles from Shonengahosha.     futekiya will announce release dates and English names for the following titles at a later date:     Ore Tachi no Hanashi wo Shiyou by Samba Maekawa   Boss to Yasu by Sainosuke   Koi wo Shiru niha Mada Aoi [Tankoubonban] by Ryo Ito   Gnossiennes -Seinen Tachi wa Yuukaku de Koi wo Siru- [Gassatsuban] by Makuya   Suki ni Natta Hito ga Barineko de Shita- [Gassatsuban] by Haine   Kouda-san! Uchi Kimashou! -Nigerare Otoko to Batsuichi Otoko- [Gassatsuban] by Taguru Nakamaru   Yuusha-sama no Are ga Cheatkyuu Sugite Komattemasu by Merino   Koi ni Kizuita Sono Hi kara [Gassatsuban] by Ryo Ito   Aseta Tsuki to Amai Kiba by salty   Kyou mo Futago ni Semararete masu by Kanna Aizumi    Readers are able to read select chapters from the futekiya library for free, and subscribers to the futekiya service can access full volumes.    The futekiya service launched in July 2019, and it allows access to its entire library of manga for a monthly fee of US$6.99. The service is also offering licensed dōjinshi and manga by independent artists.    Manga Planet launched in November 2019. The service costs US$6.99 per month and allows users unlimited access to English-translated manga. In addition to manga licensed from publishers, the service offers works licensed from independent artists.    Manga Planet is also working with publishers LEED Publishing Co., Ltd., Bunkasha Publishing Co., Ltd.; Kaiohsha Publishing Co., Ltd.; San-Ei Corporation Co., Ltd.; Tokuma Shoten Publishing Co., Ltd.; Shodensha Publishing Co., Ltd.; Home-sha, Starts Publishing Corporation, K.K. HarperCollins Japan, and MugenUp Inc.    Manga Planet started as a joint project between Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd. and Fantasista, Inc. in 2012. The companies' goal with Manga Planet is to "[bring] new manga to fans from all over the world and support artists and the industry."    Disclosure: futekiya's Editor-in-Chief Emma Hanashiro worked at ANN as a news intern in 2014.
